story:
Title: “One More Christmas” (A Top 10 Screenplay Finalist at the GI Film Fest 2015)

Genre: Drama – Romance:  Central Hero, Character Driven, Faith Based, Family Friendly, Love Story.  Overcoming Obstacles, Rural Setting, Strong Male Lead, Teens, Wide Audience, Tragedy, War - Military.

Logline:  A wounded warrior struggles with recovery, his memories of war, coming home and accepting love before discovering his true purpose in life is to help others.

Synopsis: Set with the back drop of “Bode’s Christmas Tree Farm,” the story explores important themes around PTSD and recovery.  It investigates the generational aspects of war and manhood and represents a return to family values.  It is a story about living in the real world, in a world where children are not coddled and spoiled.  The story also brings a strong moral message; that helping others is a way of helping yourself. 

Leo Harper is our wounded warrior who opens up to Dr. Birmingham about his life and how his mother passed away.  He explains that he was raised by his great grandfather, Vernon Bode, a Vietnam Veteran who lives by the tradition of the Wolf’s Code.  Bode uses the code as a teaching tool after taking on the responsibility of raising Leo and his older brother.  Bode shows the teens how to become men and how to treat others with respect and dignity.  He teaches them frontiersman-like self-reliance and more importantly, how to recognize love and what it truly means to be a warrior. 

After showing some improvement, Leo returns home and begins to balance his expectations for himself against the certainty of his injuries and although he struggles to overcome the debilitation of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder he finds peace through God, surrounded by family.  He learns that in life, what he truly wants for Christmas simply cannot be bought.  Bottom line, we all pray for one more Christmas with those we love, with those who live in our hearts, in our memories, in our soul. 

Thank you and God bless each and every one of you! 

Sincerely,

Steven B. Newman

story:
Short Summary

My name is Forbes West and I'm a writer/producer. I'm putting together a psychological thriller called "Riddle Horse". As a short log line, it's a film about:


"A young scheming pastor who believes that the ends justifies the means and an aging cowboy who won't be backed down square off against each other as the cowboy refuses to sell his desert ranch at a loss to the pastor's church; however when tragedy strikes it’s up to his trophy wife from another country and his violent daughter to keep the land."

I love writing and putting together a film. So far I've had success with a short film called "On The Border" which you can watch by clicking the link. It's been in over 13 different film festivals across the world.

What We Need & What You Get

We need about 24k to get the project off of the ground.

With 24-25k, we can film the first part of the script at the very least (to start a television series, which has been proposed, or a limited web-series at the least). In other words, we could film the first 31 minutes and have a full story within those 31 minutes. With 45k, we should be able to film the entire 90 minute film, and if we managed to hit 100k, we should have a very decent product to disclose with nothing to be cut down.

Again, we should emphasize that this is a small production with everyone having worked together before. Everyone is invested, everyone knows what to do. Money is the only true obstacle, which is some ways is a blessing. From the cinematographer to every actor, we've bonded outside the film world and know we can pull this off.

We should be able to conclude post-production by December 2016.

The Impact

If we can do this, we can really have an interesting and well done film that talks about the dark side of America right now. The film discusses terrorism, greed, religious corruption and mental illness- topics that are at the forefront of what's happening right now in the USA. This isn't a film with heavy social commentary though- it's a film meant as entertainment without any heavy handed "message".  It's a film that is supposed to be entertaining but at the same time full of deeper themes.

Risks & Challenges

The real obstacle we have to overcome is our budget. Locations have been scouted, 3 out of 4 of the main characters have been cast, the crew has been set. To be perfectly honest, all of us know each other and are friends and family who have worked together on other projects before so there should be little difficulty in getting along. The entire script is setup to be shot in chiefly two locations, neither which are dependent on the weather and neither of which has any problems with getting a film permit. To be very honest, there could be an issue with locking in one of these two settings (if for some unforeseen reason something else is scheduled to be filmed). But that seems very unlikely from what we can ascertain.
Again, we should emphasize that this is a small production with everyone having worked together before. Everyone is invested, everyone knows what to do. Money is the only true obstacle, which is some ways is a blessing. From the cinematographer to every actor, we've bonded outside the film world and know we can pull this off.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, if you like what you see, please tweet and message on Facebook. The more people know about this project, the more I think it will be of interest.

story:
Ladies & Gentlemen

Welcome to my first THORnews 'The Next Level' Fundraiser.

My main goal is to be as Funny, Intelligent & Positive yet Honest as possible.

I work very hard to make THORnew the best channel on youtube covering as many good stories on NASA, Economics, The Sun, Space & Earth Weather, sensitive Social Issues, Volcanoes, Planets, Stars, Our Solar System, the strange state of Human Space Exploration, Hurricanes, Bread & Circus and much more.

I've been pouring my heart and soul into my youtube channelfor 2 years and 9 months now and I am attempting to 'Live the Dream' by creating THORnews full time.

So I am doing a call to action looking for donations to help me reach my goal of $10,400. Which is the total of 26 weeks x 40 Hours a week x $10.00 an hour

This would give me the opportunity to concentrate solely on THORnews all day, every day for 6 months. So I ask for your help and offer a several cool rewards.

I promise to keep filling in the gaping gaps that the MSM is missing & I promise I will keep doing it with intelligence, heart and hope. And during this time I should be able to complete an awesome 2 Hour THORnews Movie compiled from the very best moments of my 722 videos. 

Stay Cool.

Thank you very much for your help & support.

Live Long and Prosper,

May the Force be with you always

God Bless Everyone.

T

Https://www.facebook.com/thornewsgo

@NewTHOR on Twitter

story:
Welcome to the Final Indiegogo campaign for the short film project Limina!

We raised $22,060 in May, 2015, but a change in direction has motivated us to come to Indiegogo to raise the rest of our production budget. 

As our current supporters know, we had originally planned to film Limina in Switzerland. However, we recently visited Switzerland to prospect for the film and discovered that it would be more costly than we anticipated to shoot it there. Due to this change in direction, we are asking our Indiegogo supporters to help us raise the funds to finish this project in Vancouver. Read on for more details.

Link to initial Indiegogo Limina campaign: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/limina-a-new-short-film-by-turbid-lake-pictures

ADDITIONAL FUNDS NEEDED TO RAISE THE FINAL PORTION OF BUDGET:

In July we made a critical pre-production trip to Switzerland to investigate the potential, and our hopes, to shoot Limina there. We met with the supportive Ticino Film Commission, potential crew and technicians and even held auditions over two days to get a sense of the talent in the region. We also met with equipment rental companies in different parts of Switzerland. Over two weeks we covered almost 2,000km by car (Switzerland is only 348km West to East and 220km North to South)!

Thanks to this pre-production trip, we were able to realize, and then come to the conclusion, that given Limina's small project status, it is financially and logistically in the best interest of the film (and the art) not to shoot Limina in Switzerland. In particular, we would have had to make some artistic/creative sacrifices in order to focus on some of the logistical complexity in Switzerland.

Rather than raising a significant amount for additional, and necessary, funds to make the shoot possible in Switzerland (it turns out it costs about 40% less to shoot in Vancouver), we only require an additional $20,000 in order to shoot and complete the film here given our network and connections in the Vancouver film and television industry. 

If you are new to this campaign, please see all of the project details from our initial campaign below.

Thank you for being part of Team Limina!

Our last short film, Whispers of Life, screened around the world at 21 film festivals, won 3 audience awards, a jury award, has international and Canadian distribution and was nominated for the Directors Guild of Canada Best Short Film 2014 award!

But, what is Limina about and how can you help? 

We hope you enjoyed our pitch video. Please proceed to read details below about Limina’s story, cultural relevance, crew, and information about our budget. Kindly consider contributing to our special and important film. Join us on this exciting journey!

*The main character of Limina, Alessandra, will be referred to using the gender-neutral pronouns: they/them/their throughout this description.

A magical gender-fluid child named Alessandra who, led by innocence and intuition, is so curious about the lives of the inhabitants of a small picturesque town that they decide to play an active part in an unknown woman’s mourning process.

Limina (plural form of ‘Limen’ – Latin for ‘threshold’) is a dramatic fiction short film that represents the colorful and magical portrayal of a gender-fluid child (around 8 years old) at the center of a story that inspires compassion, kindness and the understanding that children, too, have voices that deserve to be heard.

BACKGROUND:

In North America and other areas of the world, transgender has become an umbrella term for a diverse array of trans identities that relate to one’s gender identity and gender expression. It could be problematic to assert a trans identity onto Alessandra because they do not identify as transgender within the narrative. Alessandra’s gender fluidity and gender-nonconformity is similar to some forms of transgender subjectivity and children must be given space and freedom to explore their gender or genders in order to self-identify.

This isn’t to say that all gender-fluid children eventually identify with a trans identity, but we hope that Limina will encourage parents and families NOT to police children’s genders.

WHY MAKE A MOVIE THAT FEATURES A GENDER-FLUID CHILD AS THE PROTAGONIST? 

"Call Me Tree" is a recent children’s book that doesn’t contain any gender specific pronouns. Maya Christina Gonzalez (the author), states that “gender conformity is one of the leading causes of bullying and can have long lasting, even tragic consequences.” Gonzalez wrote the book because by “beginning early and sharing age appropriate books that help kids see through gender assumptions, gender creative kids can relax and trust that they are perfectly natural and valuable. And kids who are cisgender (where sex and gender align according to normative expectations) can know that they are part of a larger picture of natural diversity. This sets the stage for more learning about diversity and inclusion as they develop and helps dismantle gender based bullying before it begins.”

So, similar to Gonzalez, the goal for Limina is to make a cultural intervention by adding a positive cinematic example to the emerging discussion about gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids and parenting. Both gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids and cisgender kids will watch this film and learn about tolerance and acceptance. It will also help gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids to feel appreciated and less alone!

IS THIS TOPIC REALLY THAT IMPORTANT? WHY HAVEN’T I HEARD ABOUT IT BEFORE NOW?

Recent examples of gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming in popular culture:

"Chasing Rainbows: Exploring Gender Fluid Parenting" is an anthology of edited papers by scholars and parents of gender-nonconforming/gender-creative/gender-fluid kids inspired by:

A high-profile example of gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids is the family in Toronto sparked a media frenzy after being featured in a May 2011 article in the Toronto Star because they decided to raise their children genderless. The Toronto Star story became the most read online article in its history (80k hits on the first day of publication). Kathy Witterick and David Stocker enabled their children, Storm, to be gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming rather than attempting to police their genders. The Toronto couple wants their children to share their genders when the time is right. 

David Burtka and Neil Patrick Harris recently wrote a foreword to a book about the importance of gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming parenting entitled Raising My Rainbow by Lori Duron. 

The Telegraph in the UK recently wrote an article by Radhika Sanghani about Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt’s child, Shiloh that eventually made headlines around the world. Shiloh prefers to be called ‘John’ and is an example of the type of gender-fluidity that occurs during childhood that may or may not develop into a trans identity.

An article in the New York Times in 2012 by Ruth Padawer explored the “trend” of gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids and parenting (note: this article is problematic due to a lack of comprehensive research, but it still raised significant discussion about this topic).

OK, BUT WHAT DOES THIS ALL MEAN? WHAT IS GENDER, THEN?

Gender is not a binary (oppositional poles of identification as the only option). 

Gender is more of a spectrum and children often realize this organically at a young age. 

An article written by Carrie Kilman entitled “The Gender Spectrum” in the Teaching Tolerance encapsulates this best in relation to the topic of gender-fluid/gender-noncomforming/gender-creative kids.

Kilman notes the two myths about gender:

1) Gender is binary, offering only two options

2) Gender and sex are conflated and the same thing

So, the majority of people believe that “every person is either male or female, and the distinction is based on that person’s anatomy.” However, gender is more of a spectrum rather than the narrow notion of man/male/masculine and woman/female/feminine.

BUT, WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT? HOW WILL LIMINA MAKE A DIFFERENCE BY FEATURING A GENDER-FLUID CHILD CHARACTER?

Kilman discusses a gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kid in their article named Alex who is a fourth-grader in Madison, Wisconsin. “Alex feels most comfortable chucking pronouns altogether. Alex’s preferred gender descriptor is gender fluid.” 

The author notes important statistics related to the experiences that gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming face: “a plethora of binary gender expectations in school,” which results in serious and sometimes violent ramifications. Compared to cisgender children (where their sex and gender line up according to societal normativity), gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids face: increased rates of bullying, assault depression, school drop-out, drug abuse, self-harm, and suicide (see image below).

Contribute to this film and help us share this important cultural intervention.

The primary target audience for Limina will be children, young adults and adults interested in and entertained by the wisdom and maturity found, sometimes surprisingly, in young children. 

There are two specific niche markets that Limina will fall into:

CHILDREN’S FILMS 

Children’s films are often animated and forego live-action. Limina will be a high-quality HD live-action film that connects with the niche market of children’s films, family films and youth films. Children’s and family film festivals are increasing and educational distributors are seeking high-quality content for children and young adults. Independent filmmakers rarely work in this genre, so there is a market in need for good content. 

LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans*) FILMS

LGBT audiences will also find interest in Limina because the main character is gender-fluid. Gender-fluid kids are rarely represented in cinema, so this will connect with a niche market in gay, lesbian and trans film festivals.

Your donations will help us cover these general pre-production, production and post-production costs:

Pre-Production (Preparation)

  • production insurance (location, cast, crew and equipment)
  • cast travel and accommodations

Production (Shooting of the Film)

  • cast fees and crew honoraria
  • equipment rental (camera, electrics, grips, sound, props etc.)
  • costumes, hair and makeup expenses
  • catering
  • location fees and permits
  • set construction
  • transportation expenses

Post-Production (Completing the Film)

  • editing, colour timing, graphic design
  • sound design
  • composer fees
  • marketing, promotional and festival expenses

Check out the PERKS below to see what you receive in return for a contribution. 

Pictures of perks coming soon!

FLORIAN HALBEDL DIRECTOR | PRODUCER | WRITER

In 2012 Florian Halbedl founded Turbid Lake Pictures with Joshua M. Ferguson. He wrote and directed the award-winning short film Whispers of Life in 2013. The film played at twenty-one film festivals around the world and won numerous awards, including Festival Favorite at the Palm Springs Gay & Lesbian Film Festival, Best Canadian GLBTTQ* Short Film Audience Choice and Jury Choice Awards at Reel Pride Winnipeg Film Festival and was nominated for the Directors Guild of Canada Best Short Film 2014 Award. He holds a B.A. from the University of Western Ontario with a double major in Film Studies and Medical Sciences. Florian worked as an assistant director on network television shows and features some of which include ABC’s The Whispers and Once Upon a Time, Fox’s Wayward Pines, Patricia Rozema’s Into the Forest and Duncan Jones’ highly-anticipated Warcraft. He is currently working on a dramatic period feature script as well as adapting his science fiction short film script Mosaics into a feature film. He was born and raised in Switzerland and resides in Vancouver, Canada with his spouse Joshua M. Ferguson and their two cats Rex and Vael. 

JOSHUA M. FERGUSON DIRECTOR | PRODUCER

Joshua M. Ferguson founded Turbid Lake Pictures with Florian Halbedl in 2012. Joshua identifies as non-binary transgender and has a vision to ignite global change using cinema to make critical cultural interventions for marginalized and oppressed people. They hold a B.A. Hons in Film Studies from Western University and an M.A. in Film Studies from the University of British Columbia. Joshua is a current Doctoral Candidate in the Institute of Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice at the University of British Columbia. They are the recipient of two Canada Graduate Scholarships from SSHRC, for both MA and PhD research. Joshua recently produced the multiple award-winning short film Whispers of Life (2013). Whispers of Life was screened internationally at 21 film festivals, was nominated for a Directors Guild of Canada Best Short Film 2014 Award and has Canadian and International distribution. Joshua is currently developing a feature-length documentary film about non-binary transgender subjects and a short fiction drama set in a magical European village about an intuitive gender fluid child who acts as a spirit guide to fellow villagers. Joshua believes that “Film can act as a beacon of hope for those struggling with being marginalized while simultaneously deploying ways to expand awareness in a global landscape that participates in exclusionary forms ideas of cinematic representation.”

CHERYL MARION PRODUCTION DESIGNER

Cheryl Marion has been working as an Art Director in Vancouver’s film and television industry for over fifteen years on shows including, but not limited to, Smallville, The L Word, A Single Shot and ABC’s hit television show Once Upon a Time for which she shared a Best Production Design nomination in 2012 with the show’s Production Designer at the Online Film & Television Association. She has also worked on shows such as Blade: Trinity, The Twilight Saga: New Moon, Sucker Punch, Mission: Impossible Ghost Protocol and most recently Tim Burton’s Big Eyes. Cheryl’s talents also include Architectural and Interior Design and she holds a Bachelor of Science from the University of Alberta and a diploma in Interior Design from Dawson College.

BARBARA UNTERNAEHRER COSTUME DESIGNER

Barbara graduated as a dressmaker in 2006 and then moved to Rome where she graduated with a Bachelor of Arts (First class honours) in Costume Design in 2010. 
Her professional experience includes working in cinema and theatre as a costume assistant, stand-by on set and on costume embellishments. Barbara had the chance to work with some of the best Italian costume designers: on Gianni Quaranta’s lyric Opera "Carmen" for the ROH in Muscat, on Carlo Carlei’s "Romeo and Juliet" costume designed by Carlo Poggioli and co-produced by Milena Canonero and on Franco Zeffirelli’s Opera "Don Juan" costume designed by Maurizio Millenotti. 
She also lived in the UK, where she worked with the "Matrix" trilogy creators Lana and Andy Wachowski on the sci-fi movie "Jupiter Ascending," doing mainly costume embellisments and set costuming. She also worked as a costume maker on the Starz TV series "Outlander." 
Her fantastic sketches and design can be seen at: www.barbaracostume.com

MIKE BANAS EDITOR

Mike Banas is a film and television editor who has worked in post production since 1995. Born in Toronto and educated in Montreal, Mike moved to Vancouver in the mid 1990′s and began working at MGM Television. He currently lives and works in Los Angeles. Not tied to any particular genre, his credits are quite diverse. Mike has edited: science fiction, action, comedies, dramas, and police procedurals. He has worked in most formats: half hour sit-coms, hour long episodic, MOW’s, mini-series, and feature films. His extensive experience allows him to bring a great deal to a collaboration and is not without opinion at every step of the process.Growing up in the Hardcore Punk scene of the 1980′s, Mike has led an interesting life. Among other things, he worked in Iceland gutting fish, been a human guinea pig, and edited a kung fu mini-series in China. His experiences have allowed him to observe people’s interactions in countless situations, which has made him adept at judging performances.

Mike is a member of IATSE, DGC, CCE and ACFC West and has cut shows for the following networks and studios: NBC Universal, Myriad Pictures, ICON, UCP, Paramount, MGM, USA Network, Showtime, The CW, Much Music, Bell Media, Shaw, Spike, Bravo, ThinkFilm, Maple Pictures, Syfy, Showcase, MTV’s Logo, CTV, CBC, Reunion, RHI, and Animal Planet.

JOIN OUR CAMPAIGN NOW:

Please consider contributing to Limina -- every dollar counts!

You can help us right now by sharing the campaign on your various social media accounts. Our handles are listed below if you want to tag us in your tweets, instagrams, Facebook posts etc. Your help with raising awareness about this campaign is sincerely appreciated and don't forget to encourage people to contribute! Share your passion for our special film!

Kindly use this link to direct people to this campaign:

www.liminafilm.com 

Twitter & Instagram: @joshuamferguson @florianhalbedl

Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/liminafilm

Contribute to this film and help us share this important cultural intervention.
story_txt:
Welcome to the Final Indiegogo campaign for the short film project Limina!We raised $22,060 in May, 2015, but a change in direction has motivated us to come to Indiegogo to raise the rest of our production budget. As our current supporters know, we had originally planned to film Limina in Switzerland.  However, we recently visited Switzerland to prospect for the film and discovered that it would be more costly than we anticipated to shoot it there.  Due to this change in direction, we are asking our Indiegogo supporters to help us raise the funds to finish this project in Vancouver. Read on for more details.Link to initial Indiegogo Limina campaign: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/limina-a-new-short-film-by-turbid-lake-picturesADDITIONAL FUNDS NEEDED TO RAISE THE FINAL PORTION OF BUDGET:In July we made a critical pre-production trip to Switzerland to investigate the potential, and our hopes, to shoot Limina there. We met with the supportive Ticino Film Commission, potential crew and technicians and even held auditions over two days to get a sense of the talent in the region. We also met with equipment rental companies in different parts of Switzerland. Over two weeks we covered almost 2,000km by car (Switzerland is only 348km West to East and 220km North to South)!Thanks to this pre-production trip, we were able to realize, and then come to the conclusion, that given Limina's small project status, it is financially and logistically in the best interest of the film (and the art) not to shoot Limina in Switzerland. In particular, we would have had to make some artistic/creative sacrifices in order to focus on some of the logistical complexity in Switzerland.Rather than raising a significant amount for additional, and necessary, funds to make the shoot possible in Switzerland (it turns out it costs about 40% less to shoot in Vancouver), we only require an additional $20,000 in order to shoot and complete the film here given our network and connections in the Vancouver film and television industry. If you are new to this campaign, please see all of the project details from our initial campaign below.Thank you for being part of Team Limina!Our last short film, Whispers of Life, screened around the world at 21 film festivals, won 3 audience awards, a jury award, has international and Canadian distribution and was nominated for the Directors Guild of Canada Best Short Film 2014 award!But, what is Limina about and how can you help? We hope you enjoyed our pitch video. Please proceed to read details below about Limina’s story, cultural relevance, crew, and information about our budget. Kindly consider contributing to our special and important film. Join us on this exciting journey!*The main character of Limina, Alessandra, will be referred to using the gender-neutral pronouns: they/them/their throughout this description.A magical gender-fluid child named Alessandra who, led by innocence and intuition, is so curious about the lives of the inhabitants of a small picturesque town that they decide to play an active part in an unknown woman’s mourning process.Limina (plural form of ‘Limen’ – Latin for ‘threshold’) is a dramatic fiction short film that represents the colorful and magical portrayal of a gender-fluid child (around 8 years old) at the center of a story that inspires compassion, kindness and the understanding that children, too, have voices that deserve to be heard.BACKGROUND:In North America and other areas of the world, transgender has become an umbrella term for a diverse array of trans identities that relate to one’s gender identity and gender expression. It could be problematic to assert a trans identity onto Alessandra because they do not identify as transgender within the narrative. Alessandra’s gender fluidity and gender-nonconformity is similar to some forms of transgender subjectivity and children must be given space and freedom to explore their gender or genders in order to self-identify.This isn’t to say that all gender-fluid children eventually identify with a trans identity, but we hope that Limina will encourage parents and families NOT to police children’s genders.WHY MAKE A MOVIE THAT FEATURES A GENDER-FLUID CHILD AS THE PROTAGONIST? "Call Me Tree" is a recent children’s book that doesn’t contain any gender specific pronouns. Maya Christina Gonzalez (the author), states that “gender conformity is one of the leading causes of bullying and can have long lasting, even tragic consequences.” Gonzalez wrote the book because by “beginning early and sharing age appropriate books that help kids see through gender assumptions, gender creative kids can relax and trust that they are perfectly natural and valuable. And kids who are cisgender (where sex and gender align according to normative expectations) can know that they are part of a larger picture of natural diversity. This sets the stage for more learning about diversity and inclusion as they develop and helps dismantle gender based bullying before it begins.”So, similar to Gonzalez, the goal for Limina is to make a cultural intervention by adding a positive cinematic example to the emerging discussion about gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids and parenting. Both gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids and cisgender kids will watch this film and learn about tolerance and acceptance. It will also help gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids to feel appreciated and less alone!IS THIS TOPIC REALLY THAT IMPORTANT? WHY HAVEN’T I HEARD ABOUT IT BEFORE NOW?Recent examples of gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming in popular culture:"Chasing Rainbows: Exploring Gender Fluid Parenting" is an anthology of edited papers by scholars and parents of gender-nonconforming/gender-creative/gender-fluid kids inspired by:A high-profile example of gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids is the family in Toronto sparked a media frenzy after being featured in a May 2011 article in the Toronto Star because they decided to raise their children genderless. The Toronto Star story became the most read online article in its history (80k hits on the first day of publication). Kathy Witterick and David Stocker enabled their children, Storm, to be gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming rather than attempting to police their genders. The Toronto couple wants their children to share their genders when the time is right. David Burtka and Neil Patrick Harris recently wrote a foreword to a book about the importance of gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming parenting entitled Raising My Rainbow by Lori Duron. The Telegraph in the UK recently wrote an article by Radhika Sanghani about Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt’s child, Shiloh that eventually made headlines around the world. Shiloh prefers to be called ‘John’ and is an example of the type of gender-fluidity that occurs during childhood that may or may not develop into a trans identity.An article in the New York Times in 2012 by Ruth Padawer explored the “trend” of gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids and parenting (note: this article is problematic due to a lack of comprehensive research, but it still raised significant discussion about this topic).OK, BUT WHAT DOES THIS ALL MEAN? WHAT IS GENDER, THEN?Gender is not a binary (oppositional poles of identification as the only option). Gender is more of a spectrum and children often realize this organically at a young age. An article written by Carrie Kilman entitled “The Gender Spectrum” in the Teaching Tolerance encapsulates this best in relation to the topic of gender-fluid/gender-noncomforming/gender-creative kids.Kilman notes the two myths about gender:1) Gender is binary, offering only two options2) Gender and sex are conflated and the same thingSo, the majority of people believe that “every person is either male or female, and the distinction is based on that person’s anatomy.” However, gender is more of a spectrum rather than the narrow notion of man/male/masculine and woman/female/feminine.BUT, WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT? HOW WILL LIMINA MAKE A DIFFERENCE BY FEATURING A GENDER-FLUID CHILD CHARACTER?Kilman discusses a gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kid in their article named Alex who is a fourth-grader in Madison, Wisconsin. “Alex feels most comfortable chucking pronouns altogether. Alex’s preferred gender descriptor is gender fluid.” The author notes important statistics related to the experiences that gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming face: “a plethora of binary gender expectations in school,” which results in serious and sometimes violent ramifications. Compared to cisgender children (where their sex and gender line up according to societal normativity), gender-fluid/gender-creative/gender-nonconforming kids face: increased rates of bullying, assault depression, school drop-out, drug abuse, self-harm, and suicide (see image below).Contribute to this film and help us share this important cultural intervention.The primary target audience for Limina will be children, young adults and adults interested in and entertained by the wisdom and maturity found, sometimes surprisingly, in young children. There are two specific niche markets that Limina will fall into:CHILDREN’S FILMS Children’s films are often animated and forego live-action. Limina will be a high-quality HD live-action film that connects with the niche market of children’s films, family films and youth films. Children’s and family film festivals are increasing and educational distributors are seeking high-quality content for children and young adults. Independent filmmakers rarely work in this genre, so there is a market in need for good content. LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans*) FILMSLGBT audiences will also find interest in Limina because the main character is gender-fluid. Gender-fluid kids are rarely represented in cinema, so this will connect with a niche market in gay, lesbian and trans film festivals.Your donations will help us cover these general pre-production, production and post-production costs:Pre-Production (Preparation)

story:
Hi My name is Jabari Clarke-Pennegan, I am the writer / director of Kovar the web series, starring Isaac Esau Gay as James Kovar, a New York city detective who’s working undercover to find the source of a fatal narcotics supply, his investigation leads him on a trail of twists and turns, crossing the paths of many compelling characters. This fictional web series is a new challenge for me as a filmmaker, one that I’m excited to bring to fruition. Our main goals in the creation of this series are to use our talents to gain exposure,  to further our careers, to make entertainment for others to enjoy and potentially to generate revenue for our future projects through on demand and internet streaming platforms.


Those who contribute to our project will have the opportunity to receive an associate producer, co-producer or executive producer credit on the series. These are professional credits that will also be listed on IMDB, which you can take pride in and that show the value of your contribution to the project. Contributors will have behind the scenes access and invites to film festivals, events, screenings and photo ops that are associated with Kovar the web series.

While we have funding in place to compensate our actors, we still need help to hire crew members such as a special effects makeup artist, a script supervisor to keep track of continuity, a boom operator for quality sound and possibly a jib operator to help us make our camera angles more creative and insightful, this is where we need your help as a contributor.


Kelly Karavites, SAG/AFTRA/AEA, Actor, Writer, Producer, Comedian, owner of Achilles Heal Films, LLC, is pleased to join the Kovar Web Series family as Executive Producer.  After serving in the military and a 25 year career in finance, he attained his BA in History at NY's Hunter College and also studied acting at the Herbert Berghof Studio. He started as a full time actor in his 48th year and in the last eight years has appeared on HBO's Boardwalk Empire as Steve Buscemi's (Nucky Thompson) butler, numerous Off Broadway roles including the Strawberry One Act play festivals, commercials for Optimum Online and numerous Indie films appearing internationally including Sapporo International Film Festival in Japan and 2 feature films recently at the 2015 Golden Door International Film Festival.  He lives in Manhattan and is a proud United States Army veteran. His hobbies include writing original stand up comedy, violin, painting and music.




Isaac Esau Gay is from Brooklyn, New York. Current student of the Maggie Flanigan Studio. Movie Credits “Reunion 108″. Theatre credits include: JD Lawrence’s Jury Duty at B.B Kings, Code of Silence at St. Clements’s Theatre, Bedlam, Don’t Kill Me, I Love You, Fantasy Restaurant, Don’t Be Goin Deep, Forth With Complications, Limo Guy, The Blessed Hand of Mother, The Line, & Parking Space. TV credit “Taking E.N.Y.” an Ice-T Production.

story:
Half of the marriages end in divorce and the most common reason for divorce is infidelity. This trend has existed since divorce was institutionalized.  But there also has been an alternative to this, the possibility of living in a respectful but non-monogamous relationship. 

More than often people question the idea of loving one single person and no more than that for the rest of their life. Why do people cheat?  It’s common to associate non-monogamy with promiscuity or certain religious practices, but history shows something quite different.

Polygamy has existed since the beginnings of primitive humanity, but the closest idea to community marriage appeared in America in the 19th century. After the 19th century the idea of non-monogamy resurged in the 60’s and has been present since then, in the 90’s the word ‘polyamory’  was created to define the idea of non-monogamous relationships that goes beyond normal gender roles. 

Within in the last couple of years, reality shows and TV shows have paid more attention to polyamory and it has become more popularized.  More people are getting involved in this community. Their involvement is what is making it important to start a social conversation, to give voice to the people who are actually trying to make polyamory function and to acknowledge those who have succeeded.

POLY will approach the stories from a cinema varité style, focusing on two main characters, Tom, who is the leader of his triad and Brianna, as a person who has recently delved into polyamory.


     Michelle Flores, director


As a filmmaker, I think stories find you and with that said, this is how the idea for “Poly” came to me. This story developed from my own curiosity towards how relationships should function. When I learned about the concept of polyamory, I felt drawn to research about it and then I started to meet people involved in the polyamorous world who were willing to answer my questions and share their stories.


    Kseniya Yorsh, producer


As a producer, I can say only one thing: wouldn't you want to know how it works, at a safe distance, from a comfort of your home, wondering whether that would be a suitable path for you on your way to love and happiness?
story_txt:
Half of the marriages end in divorce and the most common reason for divorce is infidelity. This trend has existed since divorce was institutionalized.  But there also has been an alternative to this, the possibility of living in a respectful but non-monogamous relationship. 
More than often people question the idea of loving one single person and no more than that for the rest of their life. Why do people cheat?  It’s common to associate non-monogamy with promiscuity or certain religious practices, but history shows something quite different.
Polygamy has existed since the beginnings of primitive humanity, but the closest idea to community marriage appeared in America in the 19th century. After the 19th century the idea of non-monogamy resurged in the 60’s and has been present since then, in the 90’s the word ‘polyamory’  was created to define the idea of non-monogamous relationships that goes beyond normal gender roles. 
Within in the last couple of years, reality shows and TV shows have paid more attention to polyamory and it has become more popularized.  More people are getting involved in this community. Their involvement is what is making it important to start a social conversation, to give voice to the people who are actually trying to make polyamory function and to acknowledge those who have succeeded.
POLY will approach the stories from a cinema varité style, focusing on two main characters, Tom, who is the leader of his triad and Brianna, as a person who has recently delved into polyamory.


     Michelle Flores, director



As a filmmaker, I think stories find you and with that said, this is how the idea for “Poly” came to me. This story developed from my own curiosity towards how relationships should function. When I learned about the concept of polyamory, I felt drawn to research about it and then I started to meet people involved in the polyamorous world who were willing to answer my questions and share their stories.

   
    Kseniya Yorsh, producer

As a producer, I can say only one thing: wouldn't you want to know how it works, at a safe distance, from a comfort of your home, wondering whether that would be a suitable path for you on your way to love and happiness?

story:
Our Story:

Adam, a freshman, joins a fraternity in order to fit in at college. After completing most of his pledge process, he is kidnapped and forced to complete one final task in order to join the fraternity. In the process of completing this task, his brother gets injured and is still forced to complete the task, putting his life in danger. Seeing this, Adam stands up to the Pledge master in the name of brotherhood, discovering what true brotherhood is.



Our Goal:

To show the audience the manner in which hazing is viewed by both pledges and actives in order to cast light on a subject that few can relate to, but that many experience or witness from afar. We want to show that it is possible to attain brotherhood without the use of hazing and that true brotherhood does not come from hazing.



Our Team:

NICK SERABYN (The Director)

After redefining the mirror selfie, Nick has continued his education at LMU's School of Film and Television. He is a junior who aspires to work as a director and cinematographer in the entertainment industry. He has created a thriving branch of original content at ROAR Network and a successful production company for which he has directed films for Capitol Studios and Embrace Pet Insurance, among others.

ALLIE GALLO (The Producer)

Aside from taking peaceful walks in Paris, Allie is an LMU senior who aspires to work as a producer or sales agent in the entertainment industry. She has interned for Echo Lake Entertainment and FilmNation Entertainment, as well as LMU's School of Film and Television and ROAR Network. She is currently nominated for an award at this year's Film Outside the Frame festival at Paramount for a short film that she directed and produced. 


ALEX SHARP (The Director of Photography)

When he's not blindly hiking mountains, Alex is a filmmaker, strategist, humorist, and Canadian.  While securing his graduating year at LMU as a film major, he has continued to write, produce, direct, shoot and edit his own short films and music videos, as he's done for the past 10 years. He hopes to one day make it in Hollywood.


Why We Need YOUR Help:

-PRODUCTION

The majority of our budget will head to the production of this film. In order to be able to pull off this project, we need to rent a camera with the ability to capture the scenes as fantastically as they should be. We also need radios in order to save time by easily communicating between each other no matter where we are, a truck to protect and transport our equipment, location fees, and additional camera supplies so that we can enhance and capture the images that we originally pictured.

-FOOD

What's important for a happy and efficient production? Good food! I have never worked on a set where the crew was happier and more efficient than when they were fed something other than pizza. By feeding our crew well, we will keep the morale high and the workflow fast.


-PROPS AND MAKEUP

Props and makeup bring films to life since they are what distinguishes a decorative ring from a ring of power, or a teenager from a werewolf. While the use of props and makeup will be on the lower end in Status Quo, we will still need a fair number of props to pull off the scenes that we have planned.


-POST-PRODUCTION

The rest of the money will be used for arguably the most vital of reasons: the storage, backup, and editing of the film. Post-production is where films finally come together so we need to make sure that we save what we have and that we are able to shape it into the masterpiece that we foresee!



Risks & Challenges

Just like with any other project, especially any other film project, there are a number of risks and challenges that must be overcome in order for the film to succeed. However, we have planned this project in a way that will limit the risks involved in the overall production:

- The film will be shot almost entirely indoors as to avoid the deadly California rains.

- Everyone on the crew has collaborated before, removing the need for frightening small talk which will allow us to speak about the real issues.

- The biggest challenge of this project will be funding it because sufficient funding will prevent us from having to use a potato as both the camera and lunch. Nevertheless, we will produce this film no matter how much help we receive because we believe that this message deserves to be shared. However, we do believe that YOU can help make this film a reality! 



Ways That You Can Help With Contributing

If you are unable to contribute, PLEASE SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN because every view gets us closer to our goal! 


THANKS FOR ALL OF YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Short Summary

In a city often overwhelmed with commercialism, trendiness and youth, once a month you can step into the past at The Noble Maritime Collection at Snug Harbor in Staten Island and experience a slice of authentic New York City history. A multi-generational group of musicians has been throwing “hootenannies” there, singing traditional sea shanties and maritime folk music that tell epic and personal stories of the sailors so integral to the creation of this hi-tech city. This passionate group of big-hearted sailing enthusiasts are preserving a rich history that can’t be found in any textbook, so we’re making them the subject of a short documentary to help spread the word.

What captivated us about the William Main Doerflinger Memorial Sea Shanty Sessions group is the genuine joy they bring to the songs they sing. Comprised of folk musicians and retired sailors ranging in age from 22 to 82, the group generously share their vibrant energy with audiences, encouraging active engagement through the shanties’ call and response format. In these informal but lively “community sings” co-sponsored by The Folk Music Society of New York, Inc., one can witness the power of art and community to bring historical stories alive and rejuvenate all who participate.

After playing together in various settings for twenty years, the group currently meets at The Noble Maritime Collection housed in a historic building at Snug Harbor Cultural Center and Botanical Garden, a Staten Island institution which formerly housed "aged, decrepit and worn-out" seamen. Now beautifully restored, the building is considered the “crown jewel of Staten Island” and is a most fitting venue for carrying on these important traditions.

Harmonies, guitars, banjos, and concertinas breathe life into dusty tunes, just as the group’s energy blows wind into the sails of this almost forgotten New York City history.

On September 20th, 2015, the group is celebrating their 20th Anniversary, and we want to be there to film it. 

Your contributions will help us hire the additional crew necessary to capture the event on film, and will ultimately allow us to spread the word about the beautifully supportive group who are keeping this rare history and music alive. We will eventually submit the documentary to festivals and hope to include it as part of The Noble Collection at Snug Harbor's resources, so they can show it to visitors. 

If you care about history, music, sailing, Staten Island, New York, staying active in a community, having hobbies, or if you simply love someone involved in this project and want to support their creative pursuits, please donate.

We hope you'll enjoy the show.


And now a little something about us:

Gabriel Baron is a director, performer and creator of stage and film. Classically trained as a theater artist, he spent eight years working on professional stages in Seattle, where his directing and performing work won him several awards including TheStranger Genius Award, and two Gregory Award nominations. Relocating to New York, he directed and edited several short films, worked on a feature documentary about climate change and capitalism by Naomi Klein and Avi Lewis called This Changes Everything, and ran his own production company - directing, shooting and editing business and promotional videos in New York. Alongside his film career, Gabriel is a public speaking coach, movement teacher and clown performer. He continues to work on both coasts, based out of New York and Portland, OR, and he’s always interested in new projects and collaborators.

Leia Grossman is an educator and studied the transformative power of the arts to build and shape communities. She has integrated the creative arts into numerous formal and informal educational settings and her passion for promoting positive social change has now led her to sharing these stories through documentary film. Her personal essays have been featured on The Huffington Post and Pink Pangea sites and she has performed on the stage show Mortified. Her love of seeing older adults active in their communities gives her hope that she'll too keep dancing through the decades.


What We Need & What You Get

Since we're a two person operation, we need money to hire some other professionals so that we can make this film a beautiful homage to the Sea Shanty singing group. 

Producer fee

500

Director of Photography fee

500

Travel

600

Transportation

200

Food

100

Equipment rental

500

Sound recordist

200

Sound mixing

400

Second Camera Operator

200

Batteries, filters, expendables

200

Editing

600

Licensing (photos, music, etc)

200

Festival submission fees

300

Contingency and fundraising fees

500

Total

5,000

The Impact

With foreign investors gobbling up real estate for sterile condos and austere high rises, national chain stores obliterating authentic mom-and-pop local businesses, and skyrocketing rents pushing out artists and long-time locals, there is a real danger of New York City completely losing touch with its unique identity. This group of Sea Shanty singers is a rare and beautiful gem of authenticity, artfully and honestly keeping alive this important oral tradition so integral to the very creation of New York City.

Our hope is that by capturing the personal story of the singing group, we can help magnify the group’s efforts to share this slice of authentic New York with the people who love and live in this great city.

Incidentally, the project will also shine a positive light on the creative ventures happening on Staten Island and within New York City’s older adult population, both of which are often stereotypically maligned. We believe that recognizing and honoring our elders brings strength and love to their final years, and concurrently infuses our communities with the benefits of their wisdom and experience.

Risks & Challenges

At this point, our biggest challenge is getting a proper crew together that can align with the schedule of our story subjects and the 20th Anniversary Event on September 20th, 2015. Without these contributions, we will not be able to hire additional crew members (sound recordist, a second camera operator, editor) and therefore the quality and likelihood of a finished product would decline tremendously. By reaching our goal, we’ll be able to pay competitive enough rates to ensure a professional crew can commit to the project’s timeline, thereby raising the level of production and resulting in a higher quality film.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out - tell your friends, your parents, your siblings, your grandparents, your barber, and the sailors in your life. 
  • Share our Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/seashantiesdoc)
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Come to a community sing at The Noble Maritime Collection at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center and see the group for yourself. They meet every third Sunday of the month.

Other Ways You Can Help Here's How!

Support Us- Watch our amazing campaign video, and check out our great Perks, which include lunch with JD Power II, a piece of the US Food 2.0 Expo Board Walk, limited edition EXPO items, and the opportunity to create your own cookbook as well as the opportunity to contribute your favorite recipes to our time capsule.

Join Us- become part of the American Food 2.0 Legacy. Connect with us online, let us know about your story, what you are working to change, and inspire more people.

Forward Us– Help us by sharing Generation Recipes and great food stories with your friends to help us reach as many people as possible. Post our campaign link: http://igg.me/at/XQgXphN3z1E/x/11727702 

Post our campaign link on Twitter


Like us on Facebook 


Check out our YouTube  channel


See all the great photos on our Instagram page


or just share ideas over a dining room table. Spreading the news will help us raise awareness about our campaigns aims, catch the attention of more innovators, and attract more money to contribute to this important campaign. And, best of all, it'll help spark the conversations we need to address the way we eat today and how we will eat in the future.

Follow Us- Keep in touch with the project and the campaign. We will be providing updates weekly with insights and lots of great information.

Thank you!

story:
Bad Nursery is a short horror film following the unfortunate story of Deedee, a young girl caught in a bad situation. Broke and pregnant with nowhere to turn, Deedee ends up in the clutches of a strange backalley abortion clinic that has other plans for our protagonist and her unwanted fetus. 

Although her particular tale of woe may be unique - one featuring a seductive, singing crossdressing leader, mute hunchbacked assistant and other staples of classic horror and camp - access to safe abortions is a real and extremely troubling problem for women in the US, with more clinics shutting down every day. Our film speaks out against the US war against women, in the campiest and most chilling way possible.

Bad Nursery is written and directed by Cory Berezow, who has brought you Shadow Dancer and other films you've never seen. He is an esteemed horror buff and women's rights buff. Also written and directed by Billie Michael, a woman.

By contributing to our film's budget, you're ensuring we can buy all the things we need to make Bad Nursery a success and that we won't have to shoot it on a phone, like the above mock trailer was. The money will go towards costumes (25%), props (38%), locations fees and catering (37%).

Even if we don't raise the whole $500, any amount will go a great deals towards helping us realize our vision.

Like in any film production, things don't always go according to plan, but we are prepared to face any challenge head on. In past productions, I've had to deal with a number of hurdles including last minute schedule changes, a lack of crew, and time constraints, but I've learned from each obstacle and am bringing that experience to this film.

You've got the right to choose - to donate to our campaign! If you can't donate, don't worry - spreading the word about our project and the importance of safe abortions would be great.

story:
"Without obsession, life is nothing". John Waters

"To be the object of someone's obsession is… horrible". Tippi Hedren

AMBER - THE SHORT FILM

Amber is a short film by performer, writer and director Andi Osho, which focuses on one twisted night where obsessed teenager, Amber Gorman terrorises Charlie Love, 
heartthrob and member of boyband One Summer. 
A devastated Amber breaks into his home after learning he is to leave the band, imploring him to change his mind. At first he dismisses her but when she reveals their shared history, events take a dark turn.

Inspired by a documentary about One Direction fans, Amber is a smart, tense thriller which explores obsession, teen desire and celebrity culture. In Charlie Love, we have a jaded, cynical and exhausted pop star pursued by Amber, a devoted but ultimately disturbed teenager who struggles to stay grounded in reality. 

From Fatal Attraction to Play Misty For Me, movie fans have always enjoyed the thrill ride of the obsessed character. Here Amber offers an exciting twist on the genre, telling the story from her point of view and delving deeper into her psyche.

 "You cannot intellectualize yourself out of obsession. You cannot cure yourself of it". Nicolas Roeg

From a germ of an idea, Amber has begun to take shape. The  script is written, our team is coming together and most excitingly, we've found two amazing actors to play Amber and Charlie.  
We're really excited about sharing this story which is not just about infatuation but also a commentary on celebrity culture and how this form of obsession is all but encouraged by record companies. 
Successfully funding this project will help bring this fun, thrilling and dark film into being. 

Andi Osho (Writer/ Director) is an award-winning performer, writer and film maker who has featured on several UK and US comedy shows (Mock The Week, Live At The Apollo, The Late, Late Show) and guest-starred in dramas (Eastenders, Waking The Dead, Finding Carter) as well as features, Swinging With The Finkels (opposite Martin Freeman) and Lights Out (opposite Teresa Palmer). 

Andi has written for FOX and the BBC and her first film, Brit.i.am, which she wrote and produced, was selected for eleven international film festivals, winning awards at three. Her directorial debut, The Grid premiered at the Wasteland International Film Festival in 2015.

Zoe Waller (Producer)

 Zoë Waller is a London-based producer with a ten year television and commercial production career which has seen her work with broadcasters such as Channel 4, The Food Network and The Extreme Channel and corporate entities such as British Airways, Estée Lauder and Marks & Spencer. She has experience across several media forms including short film, long-form documentaries, digital content and TVCs.   

Adam Recht (Editor/ Executive Producer) has been editing for film and television since 1989. Starting out in documentaries, for over a decade, Adam has specialised in high-end drama and independent film and has built up a diverse portfolio from Ballet Shoes starring Emma Watson to the BAFTA and Academy Award nominated My Week With Marilyn starring Michelle Williams for which Adam received an ACE Eddie award nomination.

Other TV work includes the acclaimed BBC drama A Short Stay in Switzerland starring Julie Walters, Twenty Thousand Streets Under The Sky, action thriller Fallen, romantic drama NY-LON and Channel 4 cop showThe Ghost Squad.

Justin Evans (Cinematographer) has over 15 years of experience across documentary, factual entertainment, music videos as well as short and long form narrative programming, with his work broadcast on all major UK TV channels. His comedy work includes The Inbetweeners and The Mighty Boosh and Ricky Gervais's Fame DVD and music video clients Moby and Badly Drawn Boy. 

And of course our fabulous lead cast, Cat Van Dort and Will Finlason.
Cat Van Dort took a starring role in 'Right To Choose' a Government campaign about forced marriage; she played an endearing A.I. in 'Mistaken', voted top ten in a national competition judged by Benedict Cumberbatch and Guillermo del Toro; and in 'Peaches and Cream', which won best short film at the Dakshina film festival.

As well as being an accomplished actor, Cat has also presented training videos for "The Body Shop" and Oxford University Press's first ever interactive English Language tool "Mosaic".

Will Finlason 

Will trained at the Manchester School of Theatre and played Prior Walter in Tony Kushner's much acclaimed ‘Angels in America’ and the title role in Stephen Sondheim's ‘Sweeney Todd’ in his final year. 

Will made his professional debut as ‘This Boy’ in West End hit 'Epstein', starring opposite Andrew Lancel (The Bill, Coronation Street) and made his TV debut in award-winning BBC series, Casualty. 

 Cat Van Dort                                                    Will Finlason

Now the business part. The budget for the entire project is £20,000. It's a lot of cash but about right for a short film of this scale. We've raised some from personal finances but the rest, we're looking to generate through crowdfunding. 
So far we've had some very generous in-kind gifts, such as use of camera kit and access to a professional editing system - as well as, of course, the geniuses who operate them. 
Having said that however, we do want to ensure that people are paid. It may not be to full industry standards, but at least it's a token to acknowledge the expertise, time and energy they're putting into this project. 
So where specifically does the money go - 
Our biggest expenses, after cast and crew fees are:
Location fees - most of the film takes place in one location but it needs to be a house believable as the home of a pop star. 
Stunt co-ordinator - We have a cool fight sequence and need a professional stun co-ordinator so it looks great but no one actually gets hurt!
Make up/ props/ wardrobe - We want our film to look authentic and these departments make that happen. For example, during the fight sequence Amber scratches, punches and bites. All of that requires a top quality make up artist to create these effects. 
Clearance fees - The opening sequence of the film includes archive news footage which, even for a little non-profit short like ours, has to be paid for. 

PIE CHART


We've got some GREAT perks as you can see from the list - mugs with Amber's face at the bottom, script downloads, thank you videos, dinner with the cast, even a walk-on role. We want you to feel like you're part of our team, because you are. This won't happen without you. So it's our way of saying, thank you.


We aim to shoot Amber in London in late spring after which we'll go straight into post-production. This can be a lengthy process which isn't just about editing the film. We'll need to create graphics, mix sound and colour grade the finished film. As you can imagine, all of this takes time. 
However, once Amber is finally locked off, we'll start the next exciting stage of the process, festival submissions. 
This will be Andi's third film festival project. Her first, Brit.i.am which she collaborated on with Adam Recht, won three awards and was selected for eleven international festivals as was her follow up work, The Grid - which is still doing the rounds. 
Concurrently, Andi will also begin working on and pitching the feature-length version of Amber. So you see, the short is part of a much bigger plan. 

Sometimes people want to support the project but can't give money, we get it. So, here's some other ways you can help. 
We need leads on a house that looks like the home of a pop star. 
We also need a space that could be in a police station. 
And, of course, sharing this campaign on social media is invaluable!
Send us a video of you talking about your teen crush!* 
*In a 45 second video tell us who you had a crush on growing up and we'll create a video from them. Email us at info@merovingianproductions.com with the uncompressed file or send us a download link. Keep it simple, record on your phone, your laptop, just tell us your story!)

Thank you so much for reading all the way down to here! Seeing as you've got this far, how's about going one last step and contributing? 
We, the film makers are, forever indebted to you. If you do make a contribution to the film, we really hope you enjoy your perks, but also that, when you get to see the finished product, you'll see, it was all worth it in the end. 
Thank you. 

Andi and The Amber Team
story_txt:
"Without obsession, life is nothing". John Waters

"To be the object of someone's obsession is… horrible". Tippi Hedren



AMBER - THE SHORT FILM


Amber is a short film by performer, writer and director Andi Osho, which focuses on one twisted night where obsessed teenager, Amber Gorman terrorises Charlie Love, heartthrob and member of boyband One Summer. 


A devastated Amber breaks into his home after learning he is to leave the band, imploring him to change his mind. At first he dismisses her but when she reveals their shared history, events take a dark turn.

Inspired by a documentary about One Direction fans, Amber is a smart, tense thriller which explores obsession, teen desire and celebrity culture. In Charlie Love, we have a jaded, cynical and exhausted pop star pursued by Amber, a devoted but ultimately disturbed teenager who struggles to stay grounded in reality. 



From Fatal Attraction to Play Misty For Me, movie fans have always enjoyed the thrill ride of the obsessed character. Here Amber offers an exciting twist on the genre, telling the story from her point of view and delving deeper into her psyche.
 "You cannot intellectualize yourself out of obsession. You cannot cure yourself of it". Nicolas Roeg

From a germ of an idea, Amber has begun to take shape. The  script is written, our team is coming together and most excitingly, we've found two amazing actors to play Amber and Charlie.  

We're really excited about sharing this story which is not just about infatuation but also a commentary on celebrity culture and how this form of obsession is all but encouraged by record companies. 
Successfully funding this project will help bring this fun, thrilling and dark film into being. 



Andi Osho (Writer/ Director) is an award-winning performer, writer and film maker who has featured on several UK and US comedy shows (Mock The Week, Live At The Apollo, The Late, Late Show) and guest-starred in dramas (Eastenders, Waking The Dead, Finding Carter) as well as features, Swinging With The Finkels (opposite Martin Freeman) and Lights Out (opposite Teresa Palmer). 

Andi has written for FOX and the BBC and her first film, Brit.i.am, which she wrote and produced, was selected for eleven international film festivals, winning awards at three. Her directorial debut, The Grid premiered at the Wasteland International Film Festival in 2015.




Zoe Waller (Producer) Zoë Waller is a London-based producer with a ten year television and commercial production career which has seen her work with broadcasters such as Channel 4, The Food Network and The Extreme Channel and corporate entities such as British Airways, Estée Lauder and Marks & Spencer. story:
Intro

Hello, My name is Vanessa and I'm a current community college student studying film. My class and I are making a film adaptation of  "La Llorona" written by instructor Leonard Thurman.

We have nine weeks to make the movie and we have to "make it work!" in this short time frame we need your help! Any contributions are accepted. It is important for my class because it is a passion project, and we want to make it special.  It is very important to make our college acknowledge our strong independent digital film and arts department. 

You as a contributor will help us fund and produce our entire film! We need food, props, wardrobe, makeup sets, and some equipment to make this work! We need at least 1,000 bucks or less! We are currently in pre-production and we will be promoting along the way on social media and locally! 

What is the film about?

The adaptation "La Llorona" or "The Weeping Woman" is based on a old Mexican folktale about a woman who drowns her kids and herself in the Mexican river. Her legend lives on haunting kids across many rivers.
Three college students embarks on a ghost hunting adventure to catch the legend La Llorona and to set her free. Along the way they encounter SCARY supernaturals and obstacles to achieve their goals. 
Our world premier will take place at Pima Community College West campus center for the arts theater in May of 2016. Most of the funds will go to support our Digital and Film Arts department. 

Past Campaigns 

Last year the class successfully raised 600-700$ on Indygogo to fund their film "American Burger" We want to keep the success alive and keep the tradition rolling!

Risks & Challenges

We are on a tight deadline and its one of the biggest challenges we face as a whole class. We are a class that are very resourceful and we believe that are production will be a success! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We would appreciate it if you guys can promote our film on social media or just get the word out to your friends and family!

story:
Really now... What is an Escape Adventure?


A puzzle room or escape room game is where a group of players are locked in a room that is full of puzzles and riddles.  You have an hour to work as a team to put all the clues together and solve the final mystery... and escape the room.

This is a unique activity that requires you to interact with your environment and the people around you.  Similar to online games such as "The Room" you will need to bring your critical thinking and problem solving skills with you but in this case you will be able to actually touch the puzzles and manipulate the items in the room.  It is a fun way to connect with people face to face rather than from behind a computer screen.  You can play with friends and family, a group of co-workers or even a group of complete strangers.  By the end of the hour you will have had an exciting and memorable experience and possibly even made some new friends.

What We Need


The funds raised through Indiegogo will help cover the costs of securing a location and constructing the game rooms.  Our plan is to open doors to the public in January 2016.

**Even if you can't contribute through Indiegogo... take some time to check out our Facebook and website and follow us on Twitter.  You can also sign up for our Newsletter via the website. Then tell your friends about us and watch for updates on our grand opening!**

http://www,perplEXITpuzzlerooms.net/

story:
Hi! Our names are Amy and Angie and we are Producers, Writers and Directors from Gold Coast Australia. We are joining together for the first time, to make an incredibly inspiring Australian horror/thriller short film.

The Red Ochre Man tells the story of a group of friends who set out on a road trip to unravel the urban legend of a man who is believed to be possessed by demons. A number of unexplained disappearances are occurring around the Nation and they are determined to find out if The Red Ochre Man is to blame.



We are asking for $3500. This is our entire production budget in hope of raising as much as we can through crowd funding. Let's be frank... we will be personally financing the majority, but we could really use some help getting there, which is where you come in!

When you contribute to the making of The RED Ochre Man, you help make a dream happen, and in 5 years when we're in Hollywood, you can totally tell everyone you helped get us there!

All funds raised from this campaign will go directly into the movie, no matter how much we raise, so if you see that we've reached our goal and you still want to contribute, please do. Every dollar counts!


We have established a very talented and prestigious cast who have all had many years experience in acting in film and theatre. We are proud to be working with such an incredibly gifted group of actors.

Along with our incredibly talented cast we welcome our supporting cast who are equally talented and without them this film would not be possible. We are looking forward to filming their scenes and showing you all what they are made of.

We need to spend money on things like gear rentals, locations, wardrobe, transportation, and food, as well as post costs like hard drives, audio mixing and colour correction. Also, submitting to festivals ain't cheap! and we will be forming a very strong festival plan, so those costs will add up quickly!

Now we understand not everyone can contribute financially, so if you can share the campaign on your Facebook, or Twitter, or shout it from an open window, that would be amazing!

Thank you for your support!

Amy and Angie

story:
The Road Trip Potty was created and patented by a disabled person that found herself in need of a bathroom while traveling, yet stuck in traffic. She designed the Road Trip Potty with the female in mind and discovered that it was ideal for both girls and women. The Road Trip Potty is ideal for parents who have daughters that are potty training or frequently say, "We need to stop because I have to go to the bathroom!"

With a compact design, it is easy to clean and stores under the passenger car seat. The Road Trip Potty is your new, best travel companion!

We are asking for $80,000 for start up and manufacturing costs. We will be using a manufacturing company in the United States. This will provide American jobs for an American designed product. If our goal is not met, all funds will still go to start up and manufacturing, but on a smaller scale.

The Road Trip Potty offers a safe option for girls and women who are in a personal vehicle and need to go "potty." We feel that this product serves a real need for females to have a convenient alternative to an unsafe and unsanitary public restroom, especially when there is traffic and a restroom is unavailable.

Please share our campaign with your friends and families. By getting the word out, you can help many females and their family members who have been looking for this type of product to help ease the anxiety of travel.

story:
My name is George Karkour, I'm a Syrian-Canadian documentary filmmaker and director. In my upcoming documentary 'Who Would You Hire?', I want to explore the notion of subconscious racism in North-American societies. 

This project is important for many reasons. It delves into our societies subconscious structures that shape implicit racial biases in our behaviour. I want to propose meaningful avenues for improvement to the audiences. 

I wish I had the financial means to pay for the production costs, but I don’t. Without proper cinema cameras and a crew, the documentary's production value won't meet the standards of cinema screenings. I believe I have the skills to make this film an educational and entertaining source for viewers, but only your donations can help me achieve my goals. Be part of the production process! Join the movement!

“We think we know the world we live in, but the majority of us don’t. My duty as a documentary filmmaker is to learn and discover, to entertain and inform, to sensitize and destabilize. I believe documentaries can create awareness and understanding among humans. And though one step is sometimes just one step, it still gets us closer to where we’re going.” - George Karkour

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions at film@whowouldyouhire.info
